body:
```
That's the expected behaviour, ZAP proxy is removing the content-coding values "gzip",
"deflate", "compress", "x-gzip" and "x-compress" because those (and other) encoding
transformations are not supported (probably it should remove all and not only some
of them). If after removing all the mentioned content-coding values there's no content-coding
value left the "Accept-Encoding" request-header field is removed.

Are the encoding transformations really needed? if so, ZAP can be changed to support
them.
```

Original issue reported on code.google.com by `THC202` on 2012-10-31 19:35:37

```
Hard to answer ;-)

Modifying http header sent to ZAP was not what I expected: I was using ZAP to debug
a web service to see if it returns gzip response when I sent "Accept-Encoding: gzip".
It took a little time to me to understand that ZAP remove this header and that wasn't
the web service fault to not answer with gzipped response.

The best way would be that ZAP do not modify headers it receive and try to handle the
response.
The response panel would show the un gzipped response, a little bit like http://web-sniffer
when you check "Accept-Encoding: gzip" option, with details about compression (ex.:
Content (encoded: 42.23 KiB / decoded: 206.06 KiB). Maybe with tabs: "Encoded content"/"Decoded
content" inside response panel.
I presume that's not a little task, so may be adding an option to enable/disable the
modifying header feature would a first step.
When disabled, ZAP would display the gzipped response.

```

Original issue reported on code.google.com by `franck.arnulfo` on 2012-11-02 11:33:46

```
Yes, that's not the expected behaviour from an user's point of view, even more if that's
not documented in the help pages (or any other place). When I said that's the expected
behaviour I said it because it was doing what it was coded for, that is, it was not
a bug.

Yes, ZAP shouldn't be changing the requests/responses, unless if explicitly specified
by the user. I guess that ZAP proxy is removing/changing the "Accept-Encoding" request-header
field because it allows the scanners (or anything else) to not worry about the encoding
transformations.

As a workaround, to debug the web-service with ZAP, you can use the "Manual Request
Editor"/"Resend" dialogues that allow to send requests with the "Accept-Encoding" request-header
field unchanged.

The response panel already allows to see the responses un-gzipped (it's done automatically
when the response is gzipped, currently the only encode transformation supported) by
selecting the "Split display [...]" or with the encoded transformations applied (the
raw response body) by selecting the "Combined display [...]".
I'll add a new view so the raw response body can also be seen in the "Split display
[...]", which would be like the suggested tab "Encoded content". The "Decoded content"
would be the current "Text" view.
I'll add the suggested information ("Content (encoded: 42.23 KiB / decoded: 206.06
KiB)") to those panels (currently it's available some information regarding the length
of the response in the "Manual Request Editor"/"Resend" dialogues in the weekly releases).

The "only" things that are missing are the change of the proxy to not modify the "Accept-Encoding"
request-header field and the change to the message so the scanners can transparently
scan the messages without worrying about the encode transformations (if they want to).

I'll add the option to enable/disable the behaviour of the proxy in the meanwhile.
Should be available in the next weekly release.




```

Original issue reported on code.google.com by `THC202` on 2012-11-02 18:26:51
- **Labels added**: Type-Enhancement
- **Labels removed**: Type-Defect

```
r2422

Added an option to enable/disable the behaviour of the proxy.
```

```

PS.: could be cool to have the subversion revision number in the name of the weekly
release.
```

```

```

issue.title: Scan rules don't manage correctly gzip compressed response content

repository.name: zaproxy
repository.description: The ZAP by Checkmarx Core project

issue.body:
While doing a pentest I discovered that ZAP was unable to find an existing ExternalRedirect vulnerability.
after troubleshooting I discoverde that the original request is set using the Accept-Encoding: gzip header, so when the redirect occurs, the content given back by www.google.it (the site used for testing) is gzipped and the regexes don't work because the content isn't the real one.

Checking inside  the ZAP panel implementation, I saw that the response visualization panel perform the ungzipping of the content while showing it... so everything seems working, but inside the core all plugins contine to working with an encoded content.

This mean that all the plugins could suffer about this implementation if the original request has the Accept-Encoding header set to gzip and the server supports it. Every time a msg.getResponseBody().toString() is performed the resulting string cannot be used correctly to search for regex...

issue.title: Add content encodings to HTTP bodies

repository.name: zaproxy
repository.description: The ZAP by Checkmarx Core project

issue.body:
Encode/decode in `HttpBody` to allow to use the content transparently
throughout the codebase (e.g. `toString()`).
Support GZIP and deflate content codings.

Fix #408.

body: This issue has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
